title: Expert tips for combining travel with galleries
text:
Michael Fitzgerald Oct 17, 2019 — 9.11am Share

When Sally Dan-Cuthbert opened her new custom-designed eponymous gallery in Sydney’s Rushcutters Bay in August this year after three decades as a consultant and collector, she wasn’t expecting her star artist Lisa Reihana to be in attendance. “She was meant to be in Africa but couldn’t get her visa,” Dan-Cuthbert recalls, “so she came here instead, which I was very excited about.”

As one of the world’s most in-demand artists – with her dazzling Maori-inflected, massive-scale video work in Pursuit of Venus [infected] now showing in Toronto, and with big projects next year in Paris and for the Sydney Biennale – Auckland-based Reihana loves “being part of a global creative family”.

Reihana’s artwork "Mahuika" hangs in Dan-Cuthbert's home in Sydney's eastern suburbs. Courtesy Lisa Reihana

But apart from her compelling cross‑cultural vision, key to Reihana’s global success has been her commitment to travel and fostering relationships with far-flung curators and collectors on the ground. “I adhere to a Maori philosophy that values kanohi ki te kanohi [“face to face”] or the known face,” Reihana explains. “Relationships are what makes my work stronger – a combination of knowledge and empathy.”

In Sydney, that “known face” is Dan‑Cuthbert. The pair met in 2002 when they were introduced through a mutual friend, and Dan-Cuthbert and her husband Chris acquired a work from Reihana’s celebrated Digital Marae series. Not only does the imposing photographic portrait Mahuika from the series hold “pride of place” in their eastern suburbs home, but it has literally embedded Reihana’s family into their lives.

“Whenever I visit, I feel at home,” says Reihana, “as there is my Aunty Rongo, who I cast as Mahuika, on the wall. And over the years I have become good friends with Sally’s family. We have had a soft approach to this idea of ‘the dealer’, becoming friends first.”

In their case, it has been a friendship forged in journeying and travel – the subject, as it happens, of Reihana’s epic in Pursuit of Venus [infected], an animated history of European colonialism in the Pacific which premiered at the 2017 Venice Biennale.

A still from Lisa Reihana’s video installation "in Pursuit of Venus [infected]".

Dan-Cuthbert says that “travel allows me to see the creativity and what’s happening all around the world firsthand and in confluence”.

For Reihana: “Travel feeds ideas. Family is always with me. I often work with and include family in my work – I never feel alone.”
description: Sydney gallery owner Sally Dan-Cuthbert and star New Zealand artist Lisa Reihana share their favourite global art destinations.
